The rooms, which look out across the treetops of Central Park, feel grand but mildly antiseptic. The main dining room is colored, by the designer Adam Tihany, in muted tones of gray and brown, and decorated, at either end, with towering arrangements of foxtail lilies, and a working fireplace allows for fireside dining. The hyperattentive and hyperinformed wait staff are dressed in starchy dark suits and fat Armani ties, and as they troop silently to and fro in the ghostly evening light, the whole scene looks elegant but solemn and vaguely stagy, like a studious California version of what a first-class New York restaurant should be. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing stagy or solemn about the food, however, which is beautifully conceived, elegantly presented (on a new Thomas Keller line of dishes by Raynaud), and as varied as the colors of the rainbow. The menu, which changes daily, is a jumble of bite-size tastings, the most modest of which involves five courses, including cheese and dessert." name="nyml_long_magazine_blurb"/>\n<meta content="Adam Platt" name="nyml_long_magazine_blurb_byline"/>\n<meta content="The French Laundry is widely touted as the best restaurant in America, and Per Se seems to have been conceived, rather self-consciously, as its august big-city sibling. The rooms, which look out across the treetops \r\nof Central Park, feel grand but mildly antiseptic. The main dining room \r\nis colored, by the designer Adam Tihany, in muted tones of gray and \r\nbrown, and decorated, at either end, with towering arrangements of flowers, and a working fireplace allows for fireside dining. The \r\nhyperattentive and hyperinformed wait staff are dressed in starchy dark \r\nsuits and fat Armani ties, and as they troop silently to and fro in the \r\nghostly evening light, the whole scene looks elegant but solemn and \r\nvaguely stagy, like a studious California version of what a first-class \r\nNew York restaurant should be. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing stagy or solemn about the\r\n food, however, which is beautifully conceived, elegantly presented (on a\r\n new Thomas Keller line of dishes by Raynaud), and as varied as the \r\ncolors of the rainbow. The menu, which changes daily, is a jumble of \r\nbite-size tastings, the most modest of which involves five courses, \r\nincluding cheese and dessert. \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n</p>\n<b>Prix-Fixe Menu</b>\n<p>Nine-course vegetable tasting; nine-course chef\'s tasting, $310.<p><strong>Best Meal Under $350</strong><br/>Get the prix-fixe at Per Se. Begin with "Oysters and Pearls," and be sure to save room for the "Coffee and Doughnuts" dessert. </p>\n</p>\n<!-- END PROFILE -->\n<b>Recommended Dishes</b>\n<p>Cappuccino of forest mushrooms; oysters and pearls; chaud-froid; bacon and eggs; macaroni and cheese; snails; scallops; boeuf grillee; creamsicle; coffee and doughnuts \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n</p>\n<!-- START featured events -->\n<!-- END
